sentences: Robert Earle Spencer (born 26 June 1925 Welborn, Kansas – 19 September 1973 Fillmore, Utah) was an American trombonist and leader of a progressive swing big band bearing his name — Earle Spencer and His Orchestra.
He formed the band in 1946 and disbanded in 1949.

Spencer was a trombonist who, after playing in the band that he led from 1946 to 1949, gave up playing entirely, due partly to a heart murmur, due partly to the hard economics of big bands in that began in the late 1940s, and due partly to the band's record label, Black & White Records, which went out of business in October 1949.
In 1946, Spencer formed his band in Los Angeles after being discharged from the U.S. Navy.
Spencer apparently dropped out of music altogether by the end of 1949 – when he was still just 23 – and nothing much has been heard from him since.
The March 5, 1949 Billboard magazine listed the Earle Spencer Orchestra as a "B" Band — one that grossed less than $200,000, but more than $100,000 during 1948.
Big bands were finding it difficult to survive in the late 1940s and were faced with limited bookings; so Spencer disbanded after a gig in Dallas.
Edward Franklin Gabel ("Gabe;" 1924–2014) left Kenton as Kenton's bandboy to work for Earle Spencer as manager in 1947.
Frank Erickson (arranger)1948 notable personnel
Frank Isola (20 February 1925 Detroit – 12 December 2004 Detroit) (drums)
Anthony Robert (Tony) Ortega (born 1928), lead alto sax
Toni Aubin and Jerry Hegeman (from Fort Worth) joined the band while it was performing in Fort Worth.
Toni Aubin (1924–1990) had married Howard Ansley Phillips (1929–2010) who, from 1947 to 1949, played saxophone in the band.

Aubin recorded "Sunday Afternoon" and other songs with the Spencer orchestra, but also recorded with the Louis Ohls Orchestra out of Arkadelphia, and the Phil Carreón Big Band out of Los Angeles, California.

The personnel listed here are found in the Lord discography and the liner notes to Fresh Sound 2501.
It was around 1947, and perhaps my first recording as a sideman," — email from Geller to jazz historian Noal Cohen, October 4, 2011.

The 1947 date is mentioned in other sources including the famous 11-volume Jepsen Jazz Discographies, but seems unlikely given the number of Stan Kenton musicians present (Childers, Pepper, Almeida, Betts).
